Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CDEV2000 - Creating Your Career: Employability for the Future","description":"

CDEV2000 Creating Your Career: Employability for the Future enables students to critically reflect on their current employability trajectory, identifying where they may need to develop or enhance their employability in alignment with their prospective employers, and developing career artefacts in preparation for job applications. In doing so, CDEV2000 covers four key topics:


  • Understanding the changing nature of the 21st century workforce and your place within it;
  • Understanding yourself to enhance the development of your employability;
  • Using career development competencies to create effective career-seeking artefacts; and
  • Identifying and communicating your professional point of difference.

To further support these learning expectations, every student in CDEV2000 will be supported by a team of careers coaches from UNSW Careers, with whom they will meet three times throughout the term to provide direction and support where needed.


Excluded programs:


  • 3964 - Information Systems (Co-op) (Honours) (Undergraduate)
  • 3587 - Actuarial Studies (Co op) (Undergraduate)
  • 3971 - BIS (Co-op) (Undergraduate)
  • 3554 - Commerce (Co-op) (Undergraduate)
  • 3565 - Commerce (Co-op) (Honours) (Undergraduate)

 


The previous code for this course was CDEV1112.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"abbe7a93dba93c50fe4b322af496191a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Interview Video","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

In this assessment, students will prepare and record their answers to interview questions and submit their responses in video file format.

Formative and summative feedback will be provided in the following formats:

  • Peer review and feedback dialogue in seminars
  • Written feedback and evaluation based on the assessment standards

Assessment relates to the following learning outcomes:

  • Utilise self-assessment tools to understand and clarify values, interests, strengths and capabilities of employability and reflect upon areas for development  
  • Develop career artefacts that enable you to articulate and pitch strengths, capabilities and ideas in professional language appropriate to the audience, using multiple channels of communication    
  • Investigate and analyse career opportunities that align with values, interests, strengths and capabilities and reflect on the implications for decision making and goal setting 
  • Apply career competencies by way of formulating future plans centered on personal reflections and self-assessment for continuous career learning and development

In this assessment, students will integrate results from their self-assessments and apply career development competencies to create a professional resume and cover letter tailored to a position of interest and relevance to their career goals.
Formative and summative feedback will be provided in the following formats:

  • Peer review and feedback dialogue in seminars
  • Optional individual career advice appointment with a Careers Consultant
  • Written feedback and evaluation based on the assessment standards

 

Assessment relates to the following learning outcomes:

  • Utilise self-assessment tools to understand and clarify values, interests, strengths and capabilities of employability and reflect upon areas for development  
  • Develop career artefacts that enable you to articulate and pitch strengths, capabilities and ideas in professional language appropriate to the audience, using multiple channels of communication    
  • Investigate and analyse career opportunities that align with values, interests, strengths and capabilities and reflect on the implications for decision making and goal setting 
  • Apply career competencies by way of formulating future plans centered on personal reflections and self-assessment for continuous career learning and development  
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"23be7a93dba93c50fe4b322af496191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"23be7a93dba93c50fe4b322af496191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"27be7a93dba93c50fe4b322af496191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"afbeba93dba93c50fe4b322af4961962","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7fbeba93dba93c50fe4b322af4961979","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Online Forum Activities - professional skill development","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

For this assessment, students will complete three online tasks on Moodle that will include a particular activity and associated forum discussion. These discussion forums are designed specifically to assist students in their professional skill development.

Note that formative feedback only will be provided for the first activity in Week 2 with no mark given. This is to provide early guidance on effective reflection and online engagement, which are important components of the marking criteria for this task. The remaining two online forum activities will receive feedback and a mark, each weighted 7.5% for a total of 15% for this task.

Assessment relates to the following learning outcomes:

  • Utilise self-assessment tools to understand and clarify values, interests, strengths and capabilities of employability and reflect upon areas for development  
  • Develop career artefacts that enable you to articulate and pitch strengths, capabilities and ideas in professional language appropriate to the audience, using multiple channels of communication    
  • Investigate and analyse career opportunities that align with values, interests, strengths and capabilities and reflect on the implications for decision making and goal setting 
  • Apply career competencies by way of formulating future plans centered on personal reflections and self-assessment for continuous career learning and development  
  • Identify and build a professional network and employ effective techniques for successfully expanding professional connections

Students will explore a profession, industry and organisation of interest by creating a shortlist of targeted organisations and conducting a career conversation with a professional in an aspirational role from one of these organisations. This involves identifying a professional, researching the person and their organisation, approaching them in an appropriate manner, conducting a face-to-face interview and reflecting on the experience in relation to their values and expectations. Findings are presented in a report format.

The report will be assessed against the assessment standards and written feedback will be given.

Assessment relates to the following learning outcomes:

  • Utilise self-assessment tools to understand and clarify values, interests, strengths and capabilities of employability and reflect upon areas for development  
  • Develop career artefacts that enable you to articulate and pitch strengths, capabilities and ideas in professional language appropriate to the audience, using multiple channels of communication    
  • Investigate and analyse career opportunities that align with values, interests, strengths and capabilities and reflect on the implications for decision making and goal setting 
  • Apply career competencies by way of formulating future plans centered on personal reflections and self-assessment for continuous career learning and development  
  • Identify and build a professional network and employ effective techniques for successfully expanding professional connections

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CDEV3000 - Practice of Work","description":"

This course has been designed to enable students to integrate theory with the practice of work. Students will learn about professional practice and develop their personal capabilities for lifelong learning and work. The course centres on engaging with external partners (e.g. industry, community, government) by working on real-world projects, under the guidance of academic and workplace supervisors. Academic supervisors aim to maximise the learning from these activities with specialised support.


The course is available to domestic and international students and can be undertaken as a General Education course.

Students will prepare a 1,000 word plan for their WIL activity that outlines: background to the project, the project aims and rationale, steps to undertaken for successful completion, indicative timeline, expected outcomes, expected outputs, any concerns and possible approaches to address these concerns.

Students will receive feedback before completing Assessment Task Two. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a462f05bdbadf450be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a462f05bdbadf450be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ac62f05bdbadf450be4672f5f3961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ac62f05bdbadf450be4672f5f3961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ac62f05bdbadf450be4672f5f3961999","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2062f05bdbadf450be4672f5f396199b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will have a choice between one of the following tasks:

  1. Critical Incident and Moment of Learning Task – students will nominate a particularly important incident or learning moment and show how they have learnt from this experience.
  2. Self-Assessment and Evidence of Learning Task – this task asks students to write about their reflections on the development of particular skills or attributes that they have chosen; show evidence of that development and discuss issues around problems of evidencing skills; and identify how to improve the accuracy of thier self-assessment.
  3. Reflection about Professional and Personal Learning – this is a structured report on the development of the student from their point of view which concentrates on their own development, strengths and limitations, and what they might need to do to in the future to improve capabilities.

Students will receive feedback within two weeks of submission.

contentlets.description:
This course has been designed to enable students to integrate theory with the practice of work. Students will learn about professional practice and develop their personal capabilities for lifelong learning and work. The course centres on engaging with external partners (e.g. industry, community, government) by working on real-world projects, under the guidance of academic and workplace supervisors. Academic supervisors aim to maximise the learning from these activities with specialised support.

The course is available to domestic and international students and can be undertaken as a General Education course.

The WIL Experience Term enables students to work directly with a partner organisation to undertake a substantive industry or community project, either locally or overseas, under supervision from UNSW academic staff. This course is designed to help students extend and deepen their academic knowledge of their discipline and their personal and professional skills and capabilities. Students work in interdisciplinary groups to solve real-world problems provided by the partner organisation. The course is available to domestic and international students and can be undertaken as a General Education course.

Team Project Plan Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

This is a team assessment task. In their project team, students will give an 8-minute presentation on their Project Plan.

The Team Project Plan Presentation must include:

·         project problem definition

·         project aims and rationale

·         project plan with indicative timeline

·         expected outcomes

·         expected deliverables

·         risks and any other challenges

·         any possible responses to above challenges

Students will receive a team mark out of 10 with an additional peer assessment mark out of 5 for their individual contribution (15% weighing in total).

Students will receive feedback on this assessment before completing Assessment Tasks Three and Four.

Individual Final Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

To complete this individual task, students will have a choice between one of the following options:

 i.      Critical Incident and Moment of Learning Task – students will choose an important incident or learning moment that occurred during their project work and reflect on what, and how, they learnt from this experience.

ii.      Self-Assessment and Evidence of Learning Task – students will choose a number of skills and/or attributes that they will reflect on as follows: how these skills/and/or attributes developed during the course; evidence for these developments; problems encountered while evidencing these developments; and how to improve the accuracy of their self-assessment in the future.

iii.     Reflection about Professional and Personal Learning – students will write a structured report on their personal and professional development throughout the course including: personal and professional strengths and limitations, and what is required in the future to improve these capabilities.

Students will receive feedback within two weeks of submission.

Team Partner Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will give a 15-minute presentation with a 10 minutes Q&A on their project findings to their project partner organisation during their final class.

The presentation will include:

·         project overview (e.g. context, rationale, aims, scope)

·         findings and recommendations

·         any problems that arose and possible solutions

·         lessons learnt

·         other relevant issues 

Students will receive a team mark out of 5 for the overall synthesis and quality of their team presentation with an additional mark out of 10 for their individual presentation (15% weighing in total).

Students will receive feedback before completing Assessment Task Three and Four.

Project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This is a team assessment task. In project teams, students will write a 3 000 word formal Project Report (to include appropriate referencing) that will be both delivered to the project partner and submitted on Moodle on Thursday, 30 January (Week Four).

This formal report will include:

·         Executive Summary

·         project overview (e.g. context, rationale, aims, scope)

·         findings and recommendations

·         any problems that arose and possible solutions

·         lessons learnt

·         other relevant issues (e.g. ethical, social, environmental issues)

·         Reference List 

Students will receive a team mark out of 30 with an additional peer assessment mark out of 10 for their individual contribution (40% weighing in total).

Students will receive feedback within two weeks of submission.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CDEV3100 - Practice of Work (Online)","description":"

CDEV3100 Practice of Work (Online) is an innovative, experiential course designed to enable students to integrate theory with the practice of work by working directly with a partner organisation (industry, community and government) on a real-world project. Students will learn about professional practice (including teamwork, project management, problem solving, design thinking, and communication skills) and develop their personal capabilities for lifelong learning and work. Students work in inter-disciplinary teams with WIL Central academics who assist in maximising learning and the quality of the project deliverables.


The course is available to domestic and international students and can be undertaken as a General Education course.


The course is taught fully online with both synchronous and asynchronous learning activities. Depending on the location of students undertaking the course, synchronous workshops will be offered in two streams to accommodate two time zones, including AEST.

To complete this individual task, students will have a choice between one of the following options:

  1. Critical Incident and Moment of Learning Task – students will choose an important incident or learning moment that occurred during their project work and reflect on what, and how, they learnt from this experience.
  2. Self-Assessment and Evidence of Learning Task – students will choose a number of skills and/or attributes that they will reflect on as follows: how these skills/and/or attributes developed during the course; evidence for these developments; problems encountered while evidencing these developments; and how to improve the accuracy of their self-assessment in the future.
  3. Reflection about Professional and Personal Learning – students will write a structured report on their personal and professional development throughout the course including: personal and professional strengths and limitations, and what is required in the future to improve these capabilities.

Students will learn how to approach these assessment tasks during the Week One workshops. You will also find additional information on these different tasks and the marking rubrics on Moodle.

Students will receive feedback within two weeks of submission.

To complete this individual task, students will have a choice between one of the following options:

  1. Critical Incident and Moment of Learning Task – students will choose an important incident or learning moment that occurred during their project work and reflect on what, and how, they learnt from this experience.
  2. Self-Assessment and Evidence of Learning Task – students will choose a number of skills and/or attributes that they will reflect on as follows: how these skills/and/or attributes developed during the course; evidence for these developments; problems encountered while evidencing these developments; and how to improve the accuracy of their self-assessment in the future.
  3. Reflection about Professional and Personal Learning – students will write a structured report on their personal and professional development throughout the course including: personal and professional strengths and limitations, and what is required in the future to improve these capabilities.

Students will learn how to approach these assessment tasks during the Week One workshops. You will also find additional information on these different tasks and the marking rubrics on Moodle.

Students will receive feedback within two weeks of submission.

contentlets.description:
CDEV3100 Practice of Work (Online) is an innovative, experiential course designed to enable students to integrate theory with the practice of work by working directly with a partner organisation (industry, community and government) on a real-world project. Students will learn about professional practice (including teamwork, project management, problem solving, design thinking, and communication skills) and develop their personal capabilities for lifelong learning and work. Students work in inter-disciplinary teams with WIL Central academics who assist in maximising learning and the quality of the project deliverables.

The course is available to domestic and international students and can be undertaken as a General Education course.

The course is taught fully online with both synchronous and asynchronous learning activities. Depending on the location of students undertaking the course, synchronous workshops will be offered in two streams to accommodate two time zones, including AEST.

CDEV3101 Practice of Work (Canberra) is an interdisciplinary project-based Work Integrated Learning (WIL) course aimed at developing students’ personal and professional skills and attributes. CDEV3101 enables students to work directly with a partner organisation on a co-designed project to provide the organisation with purposeful deliverables. Students work in interdisciplinary teams, engaging in both synchronous and asynchronous learning activities including online workshops with other students, partners and academic staff, and self- instructional, online modules. Assessments include two partner presentations, the project deliverables, and a final reflection task.


At the end of this course students will have experience in working in small teams to produce an outcome for a partner organisation, have developed project management and presentation skills, understand how to work effectively with people from other disciplines and backgrounds, and be experienced in online communication and teamwork.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ae19fdaedbf5b010595850d8f49619a2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Reflection ","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

To complete this individual task, students will have a choice between one of the following three options:

  1. Critical Incident and Moment of Learning Task – students will choose an important incident or learning moment that occurred during their project work and reflect on what, and how, they learnt from this experience.
  2. Self-Assessment and Evidence of Learning Task – students will choose a number of skills and/or attributes that they will reflect on as follows: how these skills/and/or attributes developed during the course; evidence for these developments; problems encountered while evidencing these developments; and how to improve the accuracy of their self-assessment in the future.
  3. Reflection about Professional and Personal Learning – students will write a structured report on their personal and professional development throughout the course including: personal and professional strengths and limitations, and what is required in the future to improve these capabilities.

Students will learn how to approach these assessment tasks during workshops.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"178979eedbf5b010595850d8f49619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2f6935eedbf5b010595850d8f496194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9e1a3122db39b010595850d8f496197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d1f93122db39b010595850d8f496197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ffd979eedbf5b010595850d8f49619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d6cfd62db39b010595850d8f496196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Project Deliverable and Slide-deck Report ","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This is a team assessment task.

The Deliverable/Product should be presented in way that can be easily delivered directly to the Partner.

The Slide-deck Report is also delivered to the Partner. It is a digital, stand-alone presentation that is meant to be read and not presented by the sender. A slide deck contains more text and fewer images than a typical presentation, but less text and more images than a written report. The Slide-deck Report should cover:

  • Project Overview: context, rationale, aims, scope
  • Summary of any research you have done
  • Justification for your findings/recommendations/solutions
  • Any other information the partner needs to know

Students will receive a team mark out of 30 with an additional peer assessment mark out of 10 for their individual contribution (40% weighing in total).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"178979eedbf5b010595850d8f49619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2f6935eedbf5b010595850d8f496194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"32c979eedbf5b010595850d8f49619aa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9e1a3122db39b010595850d8f496197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d1f93122db39b010595850d8f496197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ffd979eedbf5b010595850d8f49619b2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b4cb7922db39b010595850d8f496192d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Partner Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

During the final workshop, students will give a 15 minute presentation to the Partner and course academics on their project deliverables followed by a 10 minutes Q&A. This will be an online presentation.

The presentation will include:

  • project overview (e.g. context, rationale, aims, scope)
  • findings and recommendations
  • any problems that arose and possible solutions (where applicable)
  • any other relevant issues

Students will receive a team mark out of 5 for the overall synthesis and quality of their team presentation with an additional mark out of 10 for their individual presentation (15% weighing in total).

Student will develop a Project Plan to contribute to their team's initial partner presentation. The Project Plan must include:

  • project problem definition
  • project aims and rationale
  • project plan with indicative timeline
  • expected outcomes
  • expected deliverables
  • risks and any other challenges
  • any possible responses to above challenges.

contentlets.description:
CDEV3101 Practice of Work (Canberra) is an interdisciplinary project-based Work Integrated Learning (WIL) course aimed at developing students’ personal and professional skills and attributes. CDEV3101 enables students to work directly with a partner organisation on a co-designed project to provide the organisation with purposeful deliverables. Students work in interdisciplinary teams, engaging in both synchronous and asynchronous learning activities including online workshops with other students, partners and academic staff, and self- instructional, online modules. Assessments include two partner presentations, the project deliverables, and a final reflection task.

At the end of this course students will have experience in working in small teams to produce an outcome for a partner organisation, have developed project management and presentation skills, understand how to work effectively with people from other disciplines and backgrounds, and be experienced in online communication and teamwork.

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CDEV6100 - Partnered Work Project (Online)","description":"

CDEV6100 Partnered Work Project (Online) is an innovative, experiential course designed to enable students to integrate their specialised knowledge with professional practice by working directly with a client organisation (industry, community and government) on a real-world project. The course is conducted fully online using both synchronous and asynchronous learning activities. Students will develop their professional practice (including virtual teamwork, project management, complex problem solving, design thinking, and communication skills) as well as their personal capabilities for lifelong learning and work. Students work in inter-disciplinary teams with engagement with their project partner and an academic Project Supervisor who assists in maximising learning and the quality of the project deliverables.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"74543457dbedf450be4672f5f3961918","name":"Fully online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Team Project Plan Presentation (A)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

This is a team assessment task. In their project team, students will give an 8-minute presentation on their Project Plan during class in Week 4.

The Team Project Plan Presentation must include:

  • project problem definition
  • project aims and rationale
  • project plan with indicative timeline
  • expected deliverables
  • risks and any other challenges
  • any possible responses to above challenges

Students will receive a team mark out of 10 with an additional peer assessment mark out of 5 for their individual contribution (15% weighing in total). Peer review and how to peer assess will be taught during the Week One workshop.

To complete this individual task, students will have a choice between one of the following options:

  1. Critical Incident and Moment of Learning Task – students will choose an important incident or learning moment that occurred during their project work and reflect on what, and how, they learnt from this experience.
  2. Self-Assessment and Evidence of Learning Task – students will choose a number of skills and/or attributes that they will reflect on as follows: how these skills/and/or attributes developed during the course; evidence for these developments; problems encountered while evidencing these developments; and how to improve the accuracy of their self-assessment in the future.
  3. Reflection about Professional and Personal Learning – students will write a structured report on their personal and professional development throughout the course including the development of personal skills and attributes including adaptability and responsibility as a learner.

Students will learn how to approach these assessment tasks during various workshops throughout the term. You will also find additional information on these different tasks and the marking rubrics on Moodle.

Students will receive feedback within two weeks of submission.

contentlets.description: CDEV6100 Partnered Work Project (Online) is an innovative, experiential course designed to enable students to integrate their specialised knowledge with professional practice by working directly with a client organisation (industry, community and government) on a real-world project. The course is conducted fully online using both synchronous and asynchronous learning activities. Students will develop their professional practice (including virtual teamwork, project management, complex problem solving, design thinking, and communication skills) as well as their personal capabilities for lifelong learning and work. Students work in inter-disciplinary teams with engagement with their project partner and an academic Project Supervisor who assists in maximising learning and the quality of the project deliverables.
contentlets.title: Partnered Work Project (Online)

Please visit WIL website for more information."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CDEV6200 - Partnered Work Project (China)","description":"

CDEV6200 Partnered Work Project (China) is a Work Integrated Learning (WIL) course that enables students to work directly with a Chinese partner organisation on a co-designed project to provide the organisation with purposeful deliverables. Students work online in interdisciplinary teams requiring the application of their specialised knowledge and skills to add value to complex project deliverables. Students also engage with academic staff and partner organisations in synchronous online workshops and complete a number of online (self-paced) modules aimed at developing personal and professional practice. Assessments include a partner presentation, the project deliverables, and a final reflection task.


Workload: It is expected that students will complete 150 hours including:


  • Project-related work (in and out of class hours)
  • Attendance at online workshops and time spent online with the partner organisation
  • Readings and online modules
  • Assessment
  • Follow-up activities as required
","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8a547457dbedf450be4672f5f396192f","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly) - China"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Project Report ","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

In project teams, students will write a 3 000 word formal Project Report (to include appropriate referencing) that will be both delivered to the project partner and submitted on Moodle on Thursday, 30 January (Week Four).

This formal report will include:

  • Executive Summary
  • project overview (e.g. context, rationale, aims, scope)
  • findings and recommendations
  • any problems/risks and possible solutions/risk mitigation strategies
  • other relevant issues (e.g. ethical, social, environmental issues)
  • Reference List 

Students will receive a team mark out of 30 with an additional peer assessment mark out of 10 for their individual contribution (40% weighing in total).

This is a team assessment task. In their project team, students will give an 8-minute presentation on their Project Plan during class in Week 4.

The Team Project Plan Presentation must include:

  • project problem definition
  • project aims and rationale
  • project plan with indicative timeline
  • expected deliverables
  • risks and any other challenges
  • any possible responses to above challenges

Students will receive a team mark out of 10 with an additional peer assessment mark out of 5 for their individual contribution (15% weighing in total). Peer review and how to peer assess will be taught during the Week One workshop.

To complete this individual task, students will have a choice between one of the following options:

i. Critical Incident and Moment of Learning Task – students will choose an important incident or learning moment that occurred during their project work and reflect on what, and how, they learnt from this experience.

ii. Self-Assessment and Evidence of Learning Task – students will choose a number of skills and/or attributes that they will reflect on as follows: how these skills/and/or attributes developed during the course; evidence for these developments; problems encountered while evidencing these developments; and how to improve the accuracy of their self-assessment in the future.

iii. Reflection about Professional and Personal Learning – students will write a structured report on their personal and professional development throughout the course including the development of personal skills and attributes including adaptability and responsibility as a learner.

Students will learn how to approach these assessment tasks during various workshops throughout the term. You will also find additional information on these different tasks and the marking rubrics on Moodle.
